Just finished. Short but sweet is all I can say. It really is a game you can only play once in terms of getting the full impact, but boy what a impact it has. I played it in less than 9 hours to complete the game (savour them in a few sessions rather than speedrunning it), but boy, the retro visuals, the atmosphere built up from a desolate, creaking ship into a walking crime scene filled with intermingling sub plots ,the music that pounds while you put clues together from disparate scenes, it all adds to a simple, but very effective game. That scene with the 'soldiers of the sea' track blaring, thinking this is a simple death, before turning to look through the slot at the chaotic scene in full swing yonder will stay with me for a while. This game is such a great concept, but it could've been executed so much better.  It's basically a giant game of Clue on a ship from the 1800's. You can view scenes from the timeline and have to piece together who all 60 passengers were and how they died.  You have a convenient book to track details as you figure them out, and you often have to cross-reference a couple scenes to figure out someone's fate. This sounds amazing to me, and sometimes it was!  It was a good difficulty and was really satisfying to slowly piece things together. 

Unfortunately, I left feeling like it could've been so much more.  The storyline and characters are very generic, and almost every person died one of three ways -- shot, stabbed, or killed by a beast. There are plenty of nice subtle clues that you have to find, but almost every one is just noticing something in one scene that reveals an answer.  With ~50 scenes in the timeline, they could've done so much more to create a unique story, develop interesting characters, and create clues that require following someone's actions through a bunch of scenes.

In terms of gameplay, every time you want to watch a specific scene you have to find the right body on a map and walk over to it. This gets very tedious and annoying near the end of the game when you just want to search through the timeline for clues.  The ending is underwhelming and feels kind of pointless.  Oh, and getting the final achievement would've been the most boring, tedious, and pointless activity ever.

All in all, I found it to be an addicting and fairly fun 13 hr experience, but it didn't live up to my expectations. 6/10

Return of the Obra Dinn is a first person detective game, set in the early 19th century. The lost ship Obra Dinn has mysteriously returned to England with no one aboard, and you play an insurance investigator for the East India Company whose task is to identify what happened to all 60 souls that were on board when the ship first set sail.

This is accomplished by means of the Memento Mortem, a pocket watch that allows you to travel back and hear the last moments of a corpse's life, and see the very moment of their passing. Sometimes you have to daisy chain using the Memento Mortem to investigate corpses that you can only find in the memory of another corpse.

The genius of this game is how well the puzzles of who everyone was and what happened to them is laid out. There is a logical way to work out who everyone is, and some of the solutions are incredibly clever like [spoiler]wedding rings[/spoiler] and [spoiler]shoes[/spoiler], but the game is set up in such a way that you [i]can[/i] brute force solutions, yet as the verification only works on three correct people, you can't just brute force everything.

The story itself is decent though probably the weakest part of the game? It's functional, and the slow reveal of what's actually going on is paced out well at first, but once you've seen all of the memories except for Chapter 8's, the remaining story is locked behind solving all the problems and so it will likely be several hours with no story progression.

Audio is excellent though maybe too absent at times? The voice acting may take a little bit to get used to, but actually works really well, and the general sound effects are on point. The music is good too, but can be overpowering at times compared to voice lines, but usually only if you skipped the voice only parts at the beginning of each memory.

It's worth noting that, while I could describe this as being a horror game, both the method of presentation and the low-poly models mean that the game is never too gruesome, and is never actually scary. Inducing fear in the player was never the point of this game, so please don't let that put you off playing this amazing game!

I honestly can't recommend Return of the Obra Dinn enough, a genuinely stand out game, not only in terms of quality, but as something truly original. It's kind of a shame that this game didn't spawn a bunch of Obra-likes, but I think that's down to how hard it is to balance the puzzles the way Return so successfully has.
The biggest thing missing from the game is a way to erase your own memory, so you can experience it all over again.

The below are some negatives but they're really not a big deal, but maybe reading this will help people understand the game mechanics better:
- Some of the gameplay mechanics are a bit awkward or confusing. Sometimes you need to activate a dead body to access the memories, other times you have to activate things within memories, sometimes new areas get unlocked and it's not always obvious.
- After looking at a memory there's a timer that you need to wait for it to run out before it will show you the face of the person who died and let you try to guess the cause of death, which is a bit awkward.
- It's not always clear what the difference is between 'spiked' and 'speared' so we had to swap those terms sometimes until it worked.
- Sometimes it wasn't super clear who was who (for example part of the crew are seamen and we weren't sure which was which for some of them) and we ended up just guessing by swapping names around until it worked. But maybe there were hints that we missed.

This is the very first from the short list that I've downloaded, and I don't regret it.

The game is incredibly charming, well-designed, and immersive as hell. It all follows a very sound logic despite the fact that *spoiler* not all that happens in the game is realistic *spoiler*. No dumb red herrings, no pixel hunting. All the information you need is right there, you just need to actually look.  Very few things are readily obvious, but none are out of the scope of information the game provides. This is something many puzzle and puzzle-adjacent games fail to accomplish, but this one does, and it's incredibly satisfying. It only took me 16 hours to beat it, but I enjoyed every minute of it. By the end of it, even though the time seemed short, I was fully immersed in the lives and destinies of the crew. That is also an incredible feat for a game with very little dialogue, and almost no animation. The comic-book style may deceive you into thinking that it's going to be a flat, two-dimensional experience, but no, it's incredible how much life there's in this simple deduction game.

All in all, I really liked it.

I had been intrigued by this game for several years before trying it. I kept it on my wishlist after reading some stellar reviews when it released, but did not buy it until recently. I loved it. 

Thematically, it captures the feel of some of my favorite books (Melville's [u]Typee[/u] and [u]Moby Dick[/u], Poe's [u]Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym[/u], Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's [u]The Captain of the Pole-Star[/u]) juxtaposed with an art style reminiscent of some floppy disk classics of the early 1990s.

Clues are revealed slowly and rarely in sequence, allowing the game to be experienced and pondered slowly. The writing is tasteful and the grim narrative is framed in a way that the player can approach it as an objective third party playing detective, uncovering information and making connections organically. The limited setting had me feeling like I had an intimate knowledge of the ship's layout by the end of the game, as though I personally had spent time aboard.

If you like a good puzzler that you can savor, this is one of the best I've played. There are no platforming or combat sequences, so there is minimal mechanical skill required to play -- great for gamers who just want to use their noggin. I did not feel like I got stuck on any of the puzzles until I was just about ready to turn in the book; luckily I got a hint that didn't completely spoil the reveal ([spoiler]it was something I had already read at the very start and parsed through without thinking critically[/spoiler]).

If my review lacks criticism, it is because I don't really have anything negative to say. This is not a game for everyone. As stated, it lacks any test for those who prefer a challenge of skill or ability. This is a puzzler, a detective story, a macabre tale of murder and tragedy at sea [spoiler] with a mysterious curse and terrible beasts[/spoiler]. If that's not your bag, then you're probably not even reading this review.

This game is absolutely perfect in every possible way except that you can't play it for the first time again.
1000/10.

The graphical style can sometimes make identifying cause a mite tricky, but it's a minor point.

Overall though this game is a hit and you can why it inspired a subgenre.

The gameplay is not immediately intuitive but very entertaining, the puzzles or not too easy and depending on your observation and deduction skills you may expect to spend quite some time on it. Overhaul a very beautiful game that really worth your time.

Obra Dinn made me realise how much other detective sims hold your hand for you to get that "ah ha!" eureka feeling. In this game, you truly have to work for even the easiest clues, and it feels SO GOOD once you solve secrets.

The UX is just bursting at the seams with flavour. The super old-school 80s era artstyle is so unique and interesting. The way the text syncs with music beats feels so tactile, further adding to that aforementioned SO GOOD feeling in a subtle way.

It's not, and it's not trying to be. Despite this, the entire time I felt like a jumpscare was around every corner. Some would call that a good thing but to me it slightly diminished what was otherwise a fantastic experience. It doesn't feel intentional, which is out of character for a game where it feels like every millimeter was thought out meticulously.

That was enjoyable.

You're put on a ship, given a tool that allows you to see someone's final moments.

Your job is to figure out who they are and why they died.

This is a puzzle game, if you don't like puzzles, you will hate this game. If you want a game with replay-ability, this also isn't the game for you.

I'm not saying that you should wait until you're certain of your guess, just that you shouldn't sit there and change your answer several times. Instead, go look for further clues, and once you find another tidbit, make another guess.

Anyways, great game, super suggest it.

This game has some really cool ideas and some great logic puzzles, unfortunately it is also immensely frustrating in ways that it just doesn't need to be.

Firstly. the elephant in the room, no matter how many people tell you there is no need to guess or rely on stereotypes that simply isn't true.  There are a number of characters where you have to make huge assumptions like, because you've seen them next to each other in one scene they sleep next to each other, this is such a tenuous connection as to be worthless for me.  There are at least two characters with no real identifying info other than the colour of their skin, not that this would be the end of the world if thee graphical style did not obscure this in some scenes.  If you are going to use this as a deduction method then present  the game in a way that shows it consistently.  There is also guesswork involved in several other death methods where people disappear.  Yes last time we see that guy there is a tentacle about to go near him, but does he get crushed? drowned?, struck in the head?  Maybe all of those options will work, who knows, but in a game about logical deductions it is very unsatisfying when such blurred lines exist.

But for me the worst is the idiotic amount of wasting of players time.  When clicking on a memory and finishing the scene you have to wait 30 seconds before the memory time out and you can progress, which is fine if there's loads to look at but when its a scene with 3 people and nothing else just leaves you sitting waiting.  When you press to reveal the next corpse, you have to go find it and click, fine, then it sends you back to where you started from and you have to follow a sprite moving at 1mph in the wrong direction and  going in circles only to lead you right back to where you already know the body is as you literally just found it.  It might only be a small wait each time but when it happens over 60 times and is completely pointless it is immensely frustrated and a completed boneheaded design choice.

There is the sound.  The music is great to begin with but its the same 3 or 4 sequences over and over again played at full volume, meanwhile the voice levels in scenes range from loud to near inaudible, both of these types of audio are controlled by a single setting.  At the very least give us the ability to separately control voice and music like literally every other game does.

And finally, the special hidden chapter?  Turns out to be nothing special at all.  Nothing there can't be reasonably deduced before you even get there and there's absolutely nothing about it that would give the books owner reason to withold this information from you.  It's literally a massive bait and switch.

I finished this game, but honestly the last 50% of it was pretty much done out of spite rather than enjoyment.  The sad thing is it wouldn't have taken a lot to fix any or all of these issues.

I really wanted to like this game, but the interface makes it extremely tedious to navigate the scenes in the order that is needed to solve some puzzles. Traveling back to each body and hoping you remember the order the scenes appear in or even if what you're looking for is in the scene you think you recall is such a shot to the leg to the pacing of the game, in what is otherwise an amazing idea of a game. 

The execution just falls flat and after a few hours of playtime I realized the immense time requirement it would take to solve an otherwise straightforward puzzle, I decided the reward is not worth the investment. Your movement speed is extremely slow and you there is no way to view a scene without walking to the corpse. For scale, there are 60 people you're trying to identify, so you can imagine how bad of a concept this is.

This game has some really cool ideas and some great logic puzzles, unfortunately it is also immensely frustrating in ways that it just doesn't need to be.

Firstly. the elephant in the room, no matter how many people tell you there is no need to guess or rely on stereotypes that simply isn't true.  There are a number of characters where you have to make huge assumptions like, because you've seen them next to each other in one scene they sleep next to each other, this is such a tenuous connection as to be worthless for me.  There are at least two characters with no real identifying info other than the colour of their skin, not that this would be the end of the world if thee graphical style did not obscure this in some scenes.  If you are going to use this as a deduction method then present  the game in a way that shows it consistently.  There is also guesswork involved in several other death methods where people disappear.  Yes last time we see that guy there is a tentacle about to go near him, but does he get crushed? drowned?, struck in the head?  Maybe all of those options will work, who knows, but in a game about logical deductions it is very unsatisfying when such blurred lines exist.

But for me the worst is the idiotic amount of wasting of players time.  When clicking on a memory and finishing the scene you have to wait 30 seconds before the memory time out and you can progress, which is fine if there's loads to look at but when its a scene with 3 people and nothing else just leaves you sitting waiting.  When you press to reveal the next corpse, you have to go find it and click, fine, then it sends you back to where you started from and you have to follow a sprite moving at 1mph in the wrong direction and  going in circles only to lead you right back to where you already know the body is as you literally just found it.  It might only be a small wait each time but when it happens over 60 times and is completely pointless it is immensely frustrated and a completed boneheaded design choice.

There is the sound.  The music is great to begin with but its the same 3 or 4 sequences over and over again played at full volume, meanwhile the voice levels in scenes range from loud to near inaudible, both of these types of audio are controlled by a single setting.  At the very least give us the ability to separately control voice and music like literally every other game does.

And finally, the special hidden chapter?  Turns out to be nothing special at all.  Nothing there can't be reasonably deduced before you even get there and there's absolutely nothing about it that would give the books owner reason to withold this information from you.  It's literally a massive bait and switch.

I finished this game, but honestly the last 50% of it was pretty much done out of spite rather than enjoyment.  The sad thing is it wouldn't have taken a lot to fix any or all of these issues.
